ability.description: Abilities provide passive effects for Pokémon in battle or in the overworld. Pokémon have multiple possible abilities but can have only one ability at a time.

berry.description: Berries are small fruits that can provide HP and status condition restoration, stat enhancement, and even damage negation when eaten by Pokémon.

berry-firmness.description: Berries can be soft or hard.

berry-flavor.description: Flavors determine whether a Pokémon will benefit or suffer from eating a berry based on their nature.

characteristic.description: Characteristics indicate which stat contains a Pokémon's highest IV. A Pokémon's Characteristic is determined by the remainder of its highest IV divided by 5.

contest-effect.description: Contest effects refer to the effects of moves when used in contests.

contest-type.description: Contest types are categories judges used to weigh a Pokémon's condition in Pokémon contests.

egg-group.description: Egg Groups are categories which determine which Pokémon are able to interbreed. Pokémon may belong to either one or two Egg Groups.

encounter-condition.description: Conditions which affect what Pokémon might appear in the wild, e.g., day or night.

encounter-condition-value.description: Encounter condition values are the various states that an encounter condition can have, i.e., time of day can be either day or night.

encounter-method.description: Methods by which the player can encounter Pokémon in the wild, e.g., walking in tall grass.

evolution-chain.description: Evolution chains are essentially family trees. They start with the lowest stage within a family and detail evolution conditions for each as well as Pokémon they can evolve into up through the hierarchy.

evolution-trigger.description: Evolution triggers are the events and conditions that cause a Pokémon to evolve.

gender.description: Genders were introduced in Generation II for the purposes of breeding Pokémon but can also result in visual differences or even different evolutionary lines.

generation.description: A generation is a grouping of the Pokémon games that separates them based on the Pokémon they include.

growth-rate.description: Growth rates are the speed with which Pokémon gain levels through experience.

item.description: An item is an object in the games which the player can pick up, keep in their bag, and use in some manner.

item-attribute.description: Item attributes define particular aspects of items, e.g. "usable in battle" or "consumable".

item-category.description: Item categories determine where items will be placed in the player's bag.

item-fling-effect.description: The various effects of the move "Fling" when used with different items.

item-pocket.description: Pockets within the player's bag used for storing items by category.

language.description: Languages for translations of API resource information.

location.description: Locations that can be visited within the games. Locations make up sizable portions of regions, like cities or routes.

location-area.description: Location areas are sections of areas, such as floors in a building or cave. Each area has its own set of possible Pokémon encounters.

machine.description: Machines are the representation of items that teach moves to Pokémon. They vary from version to version, so it is not certain that one specific TM or HM corresponds to a single Machine.

move.description: Moves are the skills of Pokémon in battle. In battle, a Pokémon uses one move each turn.

move-ailment.description: Move Ailments are status conditions caused by moves used during battle.

move-battle-style.description: Styles of moves when used in the Battle Palace.

move-category.description: Very general categories that loosely group move effects.

move-damage-class.description: Damage classes moves can have, e.g. physical, special, or non-damaging.

move-learn-method.description: Methods by which Pokémon can learn moves.

move-target.description: Targets moves can be directed at during battle. Targets can be Pokémon, environments or even other moves.

nature.description: Natures influence how a Pokémon's stats grow.

pal-park-area.description: Areas used for grouping Pokémon encounters in Pal Park. They're like habitats that are specific to Pal Park.

pokeathlon-stat.description: Pokéathlon Stats are different attributes of a Pokémon's performance in Pokéathlons.

pokedex.description: A Pokédex is a handheld electronic encyclopedia device; one which is capable of recording and retaining information of the various Pokémon in a given region.

pokemon.description: Pokémon are the creatures that inhabit the world of the Pokémon games. They can be caught using Pokéballs and trained by battling with other Pokémon.

pokemon-color.description: Colors used for sorting Pokémon in a Pokédex. The color listed in the Pokédex is usually the color most apparent or covering each Pokémon's body.

pokemon-form.description: Some Pokémon may appear in one of multiple, visually different forms. These differences are purely cosmetic.

pokemon-habitat.description: Habitats are generally different terrain Pokémon can be found in but can also be areas designated for rare or legendary Pokémon.

pokemon-shape.description: Shapes used for sorting Pokémon in a Pokédex.

pokemon-species.description: A Pokémon Species forms the basis for at least one Pokémon. Attributes of Pokémon species are shared across all varieties of Pokémon within the species.

region.description: A region is an organized area of the Pokémon world. Most often, the main difference between regions is the species of Pokémon that can be encountered within them.

stat.description: Stats determine certain aspects of battles. Each Pokémon has a value for each stat which grows as they gain levels and can be altered momentarily by effects in battles.

super-contest-effect.description: Super contest effects refer to the effects of moves when used in super contests.

type.description: Types are properties for Pokémon and their moves. Each type has three properties: which types of Pokémon it is super effective against, which types of Pokémon it is not very effective against, and which types of Pokémon it is completely ineffective against.

version.description: Versions of the games, e.g., Red, Blue or Yellow.

version-group.description: Version groups categorize highly similar versions of the games.
